Award.AwardTitle: Making Ethics Explicit: Relocating Ethics to the Core of Engineering Education

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
MAKING ETHICS EXPLICIT:
RELOCATING ETHICS TO THE CORE OF ENGINEERING EDUCATION

This Ethics Education in Science and Engineering award supports an interdisciplinary effort to transform engineering ethics education by developing pedagogical approaches that engage students in innovative ways. Engineers and social scientists will work collaboratively to study problem-based learning as a strategy to incorporate cutting edge research into ethics curricula.

The project incorporates two interrelated research and education components: 1) develop
innovative pedagogical approaches to engage with students? emotions and existing value
systems; and 2) explore how student-directed, problem-based learning can place ethics at the
core of the curriculum.

The research team includes the four PIs at University of California Berkeley and collaborators from the University of California, Los Angeles and from the 3TU Centre for Ethics and Technology at the three technical universities in the Netherlands.

The project creates a diversity of research experiences for advanced undergraduate and graduate students, including opportunities to: 1) become involved in curriculum evaluation and development, 2) create new curriculum materials and resources, 3) participate in an advanced, intensive ethics summer program, 4) incorporate ethics components into their dissertations, and 5) contribute to the ethics research community.

The broader impacts include an active program of dissemination via peer-reviewed publications and conference presentations, as well as substantial curriculum development, such as course modules, an advanced undergraduate course, an intensive summer graduate program, and a concise textbook-style resource. All course materials will be made available to other institutions through the NSF-funded online resource center, The National Professional and Research Ethics Portal (http://nationalethicsresourcecenter.net) as well as the Online Ethics Center for Engineering and Research (http://onlineethics.org). By involving students in research and curriculum development, our project enables new scholars to incorporate ethics into their research programs and teaching activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A new and innovative approach to engineering ethics education that creates a shift from learning “about” ethics to “becoming” ethical was developed in this project. Pedagogy and course content were developed that honors emotion as a necessary part of ethical decision-making and moral behavior. Taking students’ emotions seriously does not mean that students learn to equate ethical reasoning with gut emotional reactions. Rather than labeling emotional responses as an impediment to moral reasoning, emotions supply a valid source of information that is grounded in each student’s personal experience. Students already arrive at the University with an established set of values, assumptions and beliefs regarding ethics and moral behavior. Family of origin religion, culture and psychological dynamics play a large role in students’ perspectives and experience regarding ethics and morality. Exploring how different perceptions are rooted in different experiences builds a classroom environment that respects diversity and creates a platform for integrating multiple perspectives. An essential finding of this project is that problem-based learning (PBL) approaches can be employed to engage with student’s emotions regarding the resolution of the difficult ethical issues that arise with emerging technologies. Our experience shows that PBL is an effective pedagogical strategy for engaging students’ moral emotions in engineering ethics. A new PBL-oriented ethics course for engineering undergraduates was developed as a result of this project that introduces assignments designed to incorporate emotions into the curriculum. Our results also suggest that this pedagogical approach empowers students to become ethical by allowing them to redefine engineering as a socially responsible and caring profession. Recognizing that students’ preconceptions, expressed in the form of emotion, shape their moral reasoning, as well as their reception of new ethics content is central to the development and implementation of effective ethics pedagogy. Acknowledging and explicitly exploring how ideas about ethics are emotionally rooted allows students to incorporate new ways of reasoning through moral problems. Taking emotions seriously in engineering ethics has transformative potential in its far-reaching ability to build a reflexive engineering community.
